conclusion: To determine how much work is done by the frictional force of the conveyor belt on the object, we need to follow these steps:

The object is subject to a frictional force f when it is placed on the conveyor belt. The frictional force is given by: f = \mu mg where: - \mu = 0.3 is the coefficient of kinetic friction, - m = 3 \text{ kg} is the mass of the object, - g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2 is the acceleration due to gravity.

premise: f = \mu mg, \mu = 0.3, m = 3 \text{ kg}, g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2

conclusion: The acceleration a of the object due to this frictional force is: a = \frac{f}{m} = \frac{9 \text{ N}}{3 \text{ kg}} = 3 \text{ m/s}^2

The object starts from rest and accelerates to match the conveyor belt's speed v = 6 \text{ m/s}. Using the kinematic equation: v^2 = u^2 + 2as where: - u = 0 \text{ m/s} (initial velocity), - a = 3 \text{ m/s}^2 (acceleration), - v = 6 \text{ m/s} (final velocity).

premise: v = 6 \text{ m/s}, u = 0 \text{ m/s}, a = 3 \text{ m/s}^2
conclusion: Solve for s: 6^2 = 0 + 2 \times 3 \times s, 36 = 6s, s = 6 \text{ m}
The work W_f done by the frictional force is given by: W_f = f \cdot s where: - f = 9 \text{ N} (frictional force), - s = 6 \text{ m} (distance over which the force acts).
